item.title: Lisa add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "If we find ourselves with a desire that nothing in this world can satisfy, the most probable explanation is that we were made for another world." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Lisa add a quote by Walter M. Miller Jr.
item.description: "You don’t <i>have</i> a soul, Doctor. You <i>are</i> a soul. You <i>have</i> a body, temporarily." -- Walter M. Miller Jr.

item.title: Lisa add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "Friendship is born at that moment when one man says to another: "What! You too? I thought that no one but myself . . .&#34;" -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Lisa add a quote by William Nicholson
item.description: "We read to know we're not alone." -- William Nicholson

item.title: Lisa add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "No one is useless in this world who lightens the burdens of another." -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Lisa add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "There is a wisdom of the head, and... there is a wisdom of the heart." -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Lisa add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "I wear the chain I forged in life....I made it link by link, and yard by yard; I girded it on of my own free will, and of my own free will I wore it." -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Lisa add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "A loving heart is the truest wisdom." -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Lisa add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "I hope that real love and truth are stronger in the end than any evil or misfortune in the world." -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Lisa add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "Heaven knows we need never be ashamed of our tears, for they are rain upon the blinding dust of earth, overlying our hard hearts. I was better after I had cried, than before--more sorry, more aware of my own ingratitude, more gentle." -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Lisa add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "Trifles make the sum of life. " -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Lisa add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "Death may beget life, but oppression can beget nothing other than itself." -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Lisa add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "To love at all is to be vulnerable. Love anything and your heart will be wrung and possibly broken. If you want to make sure of keeping it intact you must give it to no one, not even an animal. Wrap it carefully round with hobbies and little luxuries; avoid all entanglements. Lock it up safe in the casket or coffin of your selfishness. But in that casket, safe, dark, motionless, airless, it will change. It will not be broken; it will become unbreakable, impenetrable, irredeemable. To love is to be vulnerable." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Lisa add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "A children's story that can only be enjoyed by children is not a good children's story in the slightest." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Lisa add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "I believe in Christianity as I believe that the sun has risen: not only because I see it, but because by it I see everything else." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Lisa add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "We are not necessarily doubting that God will do the best for us; we are wondering how painful the best will turn out to be." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Lisa add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "A man can no more diminish God's glory by refusing to worship Him than a lunatic can put out the sun by scribbling the word 'darkness' on the walls of his cell." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Lisa add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "No book is really worth reading at the age of ten which is not equally – and often far more – worth reading at the age of fifty and beyond." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Lisa add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "God can't give us peace and happiness apart from Himself because there is no such thing." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Lisa add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "The task of the modern educator is not to cut down jungles, but to irrigate deserts." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Lisa add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "There are only two kinds of people in the end: those who say to God, "Thy will be done," and those to whom God says, in the end, "Thy will be done." All that are in Hell, choose it. Without that self-choice there could be no Hell. No soul that seriously and constantly desires joy will ever miss it. Those who seek find. Those who knock it is opened." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Lisa add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "Now the trouble about trying to make yourself stupider than you really are is that you very often succeed." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Lisa add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "You can make anything by writing." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Lisa add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "Miracles are a retelling in small letters of the very same story which is written across the whole world in letters too large for some of us to see." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Lisa add a quote by C. S. Lewis
item.description: "Be confident small immortals. You are not the only voice that all things utter, nor is there eternal silence in the places where you cannot come." -- C. S. Lewis

item.title: Lisa add a quote by C. S. Lewis
item.description: "The sweetest thing in all my life has been the longing — to reach the Mountain, to find the place where all the beauty came from — my country, the place where I ought to have been born. Do you think it all meant nothing, all the longing? The longing for home? For indeed it now feels not like going, but like going back." -- C. S. Lewis

item.title: Lisa add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "There is nothing I would not do for those who are really my friends. I have no notion of loving people by halves, it is not my nature." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Lisa add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Run mad as often as you choose, but do not faint!" -- Jane Austen

item.title: Lisa add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Better be without sense than misapply it as you do. " -- Jane Austen

item.title: Lisa add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "[I]t is well to have as many holds upon happiness as possible." -- Jane Austen
